entry.title: US mobile testing: Minorities have a harder time getting tested

media:group.media:title: US mobile testing: Minorities have a harder time getting tested
media:group.media:description:
COVID-19 is disproportionately killing African Americans.
To make matters worse, testing for the virus is scarce in poor, largely minority communities hit hardest by the virus.
But one doctor in New Jersey is working to address that issue.
Dr Alexander Salerno is offering mobile testing for COVID-19 infections from the back of his van.
Al Jazeera’s Gabriel Elizondo report from the US state of New Jersey.

entry.title: Through tears, mother of George Floyd's daughter demands justice

media:group.media:title: Through tears, mother of George Floyd's daughter demands justice
media:group.media:description:
Roxie Washington says Floyd was a good man and father. The mother of George Floyd’s daughter held an emotional news conference as the state of Minnesota began an investigation into racism within the Minneapolis Police Department. There has been another night of protest and anger in cities across the United States as crowds defied curfews to march against racism and police brutality.
Al Jazeera’s John Hendren reports from Minneapolis in the US state of Minnesota.

#JusticeForGeorgeFlyod #GeorgeFloyd #GeorgeFloydprotest

entry.title: Experts say Latin America coronavirus death toll under-reported

media:group.media:title: Experts say Latin America coronavirus death toll under-reported
media:group.media:description:
There are now more than a million cases of COVID-19 across Latin America. Brazil, Peru and Chile have been the worst hit, with many lower-income people forced to go out seeking work, ignoring physical distancing and stay-at-home orders. A new study takes a second look at the official death tolls, concluding that they have been significantly under-reported, with real numbers possible triple the official count.
Al Jazeera’s Lucia Newman reports from Santiago, Chile.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#Coronavirus #Covid19 #LatinAmerica

entry.title: Floyd protesters continue to rally as Trump decries 'lowlifes'

media:group.media:title: Floyd protesters continue to rally as Trump decries 'lowlifes'
media:group.media:description:
The United States has been gripped by protests over the death of George Floyd - an unarmed Black man who died last week in police custody in Minneapolis, Minnesota - and police brutality nationwide. US President Donald Trump has outraged faith leaders and protesters for walking to a historic church near the White House and creating a photo opportunity, just minutes after police used chemical smoke canisters and flashbangs on peaceful protesters to clear the way for the rare walk.
Al Jazeera’s Mike Hanna reports from the US capital, Washington, DC.

#Trump #GeorgeFloyd #GeorgeFloydprotest

entry.title: Lessons from lockdown: Cities to share experiences with COVID-19

media:group.media:title: Lessons from lockdown: Cities to share experiences with COVID-19
media:group.media:description:
As coronavirus restrictions begin lifting around the world, many countries are looking abroad, to understand the different responses to the pandemic. While some countries shut down immediately, others had a more relaxed approach. Now, mayors from 40 cities around the world are sharing their experiences via a teleconference hosted by the South Korean capital, Seoul.
Al Jazeera’s Rob McBride reports from Seoul, South Korea.

#Coronavirus #CAC2020 #SouthKorea

entry.title: Brazil anti-racism rallies: Protesters blame Bolsonaro

media:group.media:title: Brazil anti-racism rallies: Protesters blame Bolsonaro
media:group.media:description:
Anti-racism demonstrations are being held in Brazil, where around half the population is Black or mixed race. The protesters blame President Jair Bolsonaro for the growing discrimination.
Al Jazeera's Teresa Bo reports.

#Brazil #BrazilRacism #Bolsonaro

entry.title: Can Trump order the US military to quell violence at protests?

media:group.media:title: Can Trump order the US military to quell violence at protests?
media:group.media:description:
The US president has resorted to threats of force as a way to control the unrest there. US President Donald Trump on Monday suggested he would use federal troops to end the unrest that has erupted following the police killing of George Floyd, an unarmed Black man, last week. Previous presidents, however, have sought to balance military might with words of compassion and calm, and critics have argued that balance has been missing from this White House.
Al Jazeera's Heidi Zhou-Castro reports from Washington, DC.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#Trump #GeorgeFloyd #GeorgeFloydprotest

entry.title: George Floyd: Mass protests continue to erupt across the US - Live updates

media:group.media:title: George Floyd: Mass protests continue to erupt across the US - Live updates
media:group.media:description:
The family of George Floyd has made an emotional appeal for justice, as protests continue across the country, despite curfews and threats of force. Floyd's death has sparked days of protests - including in Washington, DC. The US President Donald Trump has come under criticism for his handling of the tense situation, in particular, the forcible removal of protesters outside the White House, so that he could have a photo-op at a nearby church. Protests are continuing across the country. Curfews are in place in many cities to keep order. The protests have been mostly peaceful during the day, but nightfall has brought some looting and vandalism in certain areas.
Al Jazeera has reporters standing by in four major US cities: Al Jazeera's Shihab Rattansi is in Washington, DC, John Hendren is in Minneapolis, Gabriel Elizondo is in New York and Rob Reynolds is in Los Angeles.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#JusticeForGeorgeFlyod #GeorgeFloyd #GeorgeFloydprotest

entry.title: Can the Navajo Nation survive coronavirus?

media:group.media:title: Can the Navajo Nation survive coronavirus?
media:group.media:description:
Native American communities are so disproportionately affected by the coronavirus that the Navajo Nation, the largest reservation in the US, has a higher per-capita infection rate than any state in the nation.
This week the tribe’s death toll reached at least 241 with as many as 5,250 people testing positive.
Stemming the tide has proven a monumental task given years of federal government neglect, a lack of running water, high rates of chronic illness and an ageing population. In an attempt to stop the spread of the virus, tribal leaders have instituted as many as seven weekend lockdowns during which nobody was permitted to leave or enter the reservation.
Despite the challenges, younger people have stepped up and played a pivotal role in their community’s grassroots response. Many feel it’s on their shoulders to protect their elders lives and ensure their traditions are passed down.
In this episode of the Stream we meet people from the Navajo Nation and ask why they are so disproportionately affected and what can be done to turn the tide. Join the conversation: TWITTER: https://twitter.com/AJStream FACEBOOK: http://www.facebook.com/AJStream Subscribe to our channel http://bit.ly/AJSubscribe
#Aljazeeraenglish #News #AJStream

entry.title: Can the military control unrest in the US? I Inside Story

media:group.media:title: Can the military control unrest in the US? I Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
Many are calling for a 'healing speech' from president Donald Trump, tackling racial inequality and police reform head on. Those are the demands of many protesters outraged over the death of black American George Floyd at the hands of a police officer. After several nights of the worst unrest in decades, Trump had this message: He is the president of law and order. He said he's an ally of peaceful protesters, but threatened to deploy the military if local officials fail to take control. But is that the answer to growing public anger? And will his speech give it more momentum?
Presenter: Kim Vinell
Guests Niambi Carter, Assistant Professor of Political Science at Howard University Mohammed Cherkaoui, Political Analyst Jennifer Victor, Associate Professor of Political Science, George Mason University
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#AlJazeeraEnglish #BlackLivesMatter #InsideStory

entry.title: Netherlands reopens with strict social distancing rules

media:group.media:title: Netherlands reopens with strict social distancing rules
media:group.media:description:
Crowds have been out across the Netherlands as bars, restaurants, museums and theatres were allowed to reopen. The number of new infections has dropped steadily in recent weeks there, but businesses have been told to enforce strict social distancing rules. Al Jazeera's Step Vaessen reports from Amsterdam.

entry.title: Can Lebanon come back from the brink? | The Stream

media:group.media:title: Can Lebanon come back from the brink? | The Stream
media:group.media:description:
“Lebanon’s finished.” That’s the prevailing sentiment among many residents in this nation these days, as it grapples with the worst economic crisis in its history.
Today, nearly half of Lebanon’s six million people live below the poverty line. More than a third of the working population is unemployed, and the nation’s currency has lost 60 percent of its value against the US dollar.
The situation has spiraled since March, when the country defaulted on a foreign debt for the first time.
Protests over the fallout of the financial collapse were briefly put on hold by a months-long lockdown that has succeeded in curbing cases of the coronavirus within the country.
But demonstrations are flaring up again because the pandemic has made it harder for people to afford basic items like food and clothing.
Lebanon's newest set of leaders have proposed a “recovery plan” to woo international aid. But analysts warn that there are no easy fixes for decades of corruption, sectarianism and complicated geopolitics.
In this episode we ask, can Lebanon come back from the brink? Join the conversation.
Join the conversation: TWITTER: https://twitter.com/AJStream FACEBOOK: http://www.facebook.com/AJStream Subscribe to our channel http://bit.ly/AJSubscribe
#lebanon #ajstream #aljazeeraenglish #coronavirus

entry.title: Philippines workers resort to bicycles amid lockdown

media:group.media:title: Philippines workers resort to bicycles amid lockdown
media:group.media:description:
During the coronavirus lockdown in the Philippines capital, Manila, thousands of essential workers have resorted to bicycles - after public transport was shut. And now, as restrictions are beginning to ease, it is hoped the new two-wheel habit will stick around. Al Jazeera's Jamela Alindogan reports.

entry.title: Denmark drive-in football matches attracts crowds

media:group.media:title: Denmark drive-in football matches attracts crowds
media:group.media:description:
Football has returned to Denmark, but behind closed doors. One club has found a creative solution to help fans enjoy the action. Al Jazeera's Simi Jan reports from the Danish city of Herning.

entry.title: Private autopsy offers evidence in George Floyd killing

media:group.media:title: Private autopsy offers evidence in George Floyd killing
media:group.media:description:
A private autopsy report offers new damning evidence against the officers who arrested George Floyd. The document describes his death as "murder". Al Jazeera's John Hendren has more from Minneapolis, United States.
